column4: i tried to connect via ssh to a computer in my lan and i get this error: @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@
@    WARNING: REMOTE HOST IDENTIFICATION HAS CHANGED!     @
IT IS POSSIBLE THAT SOMEONE IS DOING SOMETHING NASTY!
Someone could be eavesdropping on you right now (man-in-the-middle attack)!
It is also possible that the RSA host key has just been changed.
The fingerprint for the RSA key sent by the remote host is
you need to remove the key that is being referenced from ~/.ssh/known_hosts
all that means is that the server you are ssh'ing into has changed its key, and you have a different key in your known_hosts
and the nixternal? i have to create other key? how could that happen (the key change?) )?
if you look closely to that error message you will see a line number that contains the key in question
ya i see nixternal. should i use that one?
no, no need to create another key..all you have to do is edit the ~/.ssh/known_hosts and remove the key in there
edit the known_hosts on the computer you are ssh'ing from
the file is full of strange chars and i don't know what key to delete. edited the file from  the pc that i am trying to make the connection nixternal
